div.p: This is a set of rules, which represent the aspects dealt with in the HM3 rule book. It is difficult to distinguish between in-world and out-world rules in HM3 as published. Since our aim is to simplify, we will not rewrite all rules accordingly, but rather rather stay with the rules as written. When appropriate we mention the distinction between in- and out-world.

Sometimes people ask, why rewrite the rules, if the way that they adjucate situations changes only slightly and this only adds another layer of complexity. In fact, we add a layer of simplification. The benefit of better scaling and other issues that are better addressed warrant the effort. The previous versions of the rules, however, clouded that, because we attempted to rewrite them so as to look original. This is no longer attempted, but we only explain how these met-rules are applied.

This describes the main out-world rule. A new type of roll is introduced, the stop roll. You roll a d5 until you get a 1 and then count the number of dice that did not show up a 1. That is the same as the number of dice you actually rolled minus one. This roll is made by the active character, or more generally, the actor. It will generate positive numbers (or zero) and is termed the positive roll and abbreviated as p5. Example: Peter rolls 5, 3, 8, 10, 2 (in that order) on a d10. He simulates the d5 by taking the result of a d10, halving it and rounding up. He thus rolled 3, 2, 4, 5, 1, on a d5 effectively. His p5 roll would be a 4.

Of course, there is a negative roll that is associated with the passive resistance or the impediment. It is handled in the same way but the negative value is taken instead. Thus in the above example, we would take -4 as result of a negative roll; therefore we can simply denote the roll as -p5. These two numbers (from different rolls) are added. The result will be a whole number, called n5 (n for neutral). More examples are provided in the generic ruleset. We only repeat the main table for convenience.
The general rules also talk about adding skills. We repeat the table provided in that ruleset and also have an automated formula here (Html only) when more precise values are requested.

When using the tables, take the two numbers and use the (positive) difference of the two in the first row, to read off a result in the second, and add this result to the bigger to get the end result. Looking at the tables, you see the reduction in effectiveness when adding smaller numbers to higher ones. Sometimes, to ease writing, we denote addition of skill (or task) numbers with +5, e.g. 1 +5 2. This is called 5-Addition, because 0 +5 0 = 5.

Whenever we have ML, SB or other technical terms, we append an U to distinguish the Universal rules, from the classic. E.g. MLU and SBU. You can calculate MLU as ML * 0.4. The basic 50/50 chance of success on a skill roll is with an ML of 50%, i.e. an MLU of 20. Thus the most basic task difficulty - all other things being equal - should be set to 20.

Skills govern all activities, from combat to spell-casting. All skills are rated on an open scale starting from zero (0), with only 10% reaching 10 points more. This general situation is in-world knowledge. But this is also identical with the p5 system of rolling dice, which is out-world. The skill scale is open-ended as the p5 roll is, but humans generally do not get scores beyond 50 (out-world).
The following is a list of skills that are commonly used by characters on Hârn. It is neither complete no without overlap.

Skill Development is set up such that about 20% of MLU of n have MLU+10. Since everyone has at least MLU 0, for normal cases, this means that about 3 in 10000 have MLU of 50. Individual may be awarded by the GM at any time, when something was “learned” (this is out-world). Remember that you learn most from failures. Some skills may be developed by practice/study, some require training. When you need time to learn, read this from the following table. I.e. the better you already are, the harder it is to improve.

Some skill require that a teacher is present at the beginning of a skill career, e.g. because a Lnaguags cannot be learned without someone who actually speaks it reasonably well, or “glass blower trade secret” are imparted. This is mentioned with the approproate skill.

In all cases, GM discretion is highly advised. When a mentor, coach, or teacher is available it can improve learning speed. But materials may be of bad quality or study time is interrupted frequently. The time to increase an MLU this way should usually be within 20% of the listed number. (A more thorough rule can be devised, but this does not seem to be of general interest.
Sometimes forgetting or “unlearning” is called for. If skill has not been used for as many days is stated in the table to learn something, deduct a point.

Improving Specialties is a bit more elaborate. Skills list specialties with a percentage value. This percentage value gives the approximate part of the whole group that this specialization comprises. When the skill is improved (the skill group of all specialties) all improvement may be dedicated to the specialty instead. As an example, a Specialty/20 could see an improvement of 5 points instead of a 1 for the group and a 40% Specialty an improvement of 2.5 points of the specialty instead of 1 for the group. So, divide 100% by the given percentage to get a multiple m. The time needed is the average of all the MLU points improved according to the basic law.

Note: If at any time the skill group itself is developed, specialties are only improved, if they would fall below the MLU of the group otherwise. It would be prudent to learn the “opposite” Specialty.

Dimensions are collected as common reference for the many skills that use them in more or less the same manner. They determine a frame of reference for the difficulties of tasks. They can also used in-world, but are more regularly used out-world, when a PC tries to achieve a concrete goal.

Attributes come in textual form and a few in numeric form. The numeric attributes are listed above separately. To have an appropriate scale, and keep the rule, just keep the attribute as-is. Everything else, including the star-scale follows from there.

When an attribute roll is called for, it comes in two forms. The first treats the attribute as a ficticious skill with an ML as a multiple of the attribute. This form is treated as any MLU. Say, Strength is 9 and a roll vs. 2 x Strength is called for. The MLU is 7 and the task level is 20 (default).

The second version is rolling n number of d6, summing them up and stay below an attribute value. This does not fit well into the scheme, but the spirit is obviously that with each additional die the chances to succeed become sharply worse. Treat 1d6 as task level 0, 2d6 as task level 5, 3d6 as 10, and so on.

Many skills can be divided into sub-skills or specialties; suggestions are given with some skills. Characters may select specialties at any time. The skill is then termed a group skill and includes all (potential) specialties, even if unknown. The specific specialty skill is opened at the current group MLU (note that the ML can be calculated from that, if needed). Each specialty is developed as a separate skill.

Sometimes, only Specialties are given and the question arises, what MLU in the Specialty applies to the skill group. Each specialty has a percentage value associated with it. (For a new Specialty, this must be decided upon by the GM.) Take that percentage of Specialty MLU to get the group’s MLU. For example, a Mask/20% specialty in Woodcraft of 12 would imply a Woodcraft group score of 2.4, rounded down to 2. This applies only to MLU. OML (if specialization is attempted at the outset) is as for the group skill.
Sunsigns represent an astrological affinity to certain skills in-world, see original rules. They give a direct bonus to the MLU.

MLU is modified for a concrete test due to various circumstance resulting in an EMLU. Only minor additions or subtractions are considered. In the odd case, where original rules call for taking half of the ML, subtract 10 from the MLU.

When a character attempts to use a skill, n5 is rolled, adding EMLU. The GM will have decided upon a diffculty level of the task, often called the negative part. Some modfifiers are compounded here, although this makes no difference, whether it were included in the EMLU instead. This value is also subtracted from the roll and if the net result is non-negative, the skill has been successfully employed; if the roll is negative, the attempt has failed. For example, if a PC declares the intent to perform a gymnastic feat, the GM would instruct the player to “test Acrobatics against difficulty 15.” In cases where success or failure may not be obvious, the GM should make the roll secretly.

It is often necessary to know the degree of success or failure. The skill descriptions provide these so-called dimensions. For skills, where no appropriate success levels are provided or for newly devised skills, estimate the effects by looking at the skills most closely related.

When two characters use skills against each other, each character makes a p5 skill roll appropriate to the skill in question and the results are compared to give a net result. The descriptions of the two skills should match this net result (they should obviously be the negative of each other). The character with the higher result wins the challenge. If both characters achieve the same success level, the stalemate result of zero (0) applies. If a tie is not appropriate to the situation, then decimal place may be rolled as explained in the initial section.
Penalties are added to the task difficulty and rated at 40% of the original value. For instance, a S10 wound turns into a -4 IPU.

Situations or skill applications can either fit to a certain skill fully or only partially. Sometimes multiple skills may apply. In any given situation, the GM will state the skills that apply and to what percentage. Then use a weighted average as skill. Example: The GM rules that performing a ballet, is 60% Acrobatics and 40% Dancing non-overlapping. A character with MLU Acrobatics/16 and MLU Dancing/11 has MLU Ballet/14.

Multiple attackers can combine their efforts through 5-Addition into one. This is generally a complex topic, because modifiers need to be accommodated as they enter the game, so this is best reserved for NPCs that perform as single units. Multiple defendants are similarly added. An exception to this is mounted combat, where PC rider and horse may be acting in unison.

The following shows example dimensions for the various skills, usually only the dominant ones. Finding the appropriate dimension depends on the concrete circumstances. Consider what would be appropriate for an untrained individual (MLU 0) and what is expected (the average result) for a sufficiently educated persion (MLU 20). Interprete the results inbetween and outside of the bounds accordingly.

Judging the values of goods produced or performances delivered works the same for almost all skills. This is different from the commercial value, which depends on a lot of other factors (market size, etc). The rare occasion, where the MLU of the actor cannot be judged are at GM discretion. I.e. someone who successfully evades perception cannot be judged on this “performance” by the potentially fooled or only in the most general sense. The value in parenthesis is the range by which the estimation may be off. It is calculated from the percentage value x by the range (100% - x) to 1/(100% - x).
The skill is used for multiple purposes; to avoid falling objects, weapon and missile attacks, and other situations requiring Agility. See Combat for a relevant dimension.

Hârn Manor shows that the following dimension is useful: assume a standard task level of 20 and adjust the result for any applicable modifiers (such as Hardiness Rating), the resulting net value gives the percentage of the crop yield that is in excess or short of the 100%. (See Hârn Manor 29.) For example, if the MLU is 20, all modifiers are a total of -10 and the roll itself + +5, then the net value is -5, resulting in a crop yield of 95% in the given year.
The Recipe dimension is commonly used.
Sleeping adds at least 10 to any task difficulty. Loud noises give a bonus to the Skill roll.

Speed is measured as a factor to normal (walk) move. A running total of vertical progress is kept to determine when the climb is complete, and the extent of any fall. A single scale should only be rolled once, but any interruption, such as rest requires a new roll. Any negative speed result (n5 net result below 0) implies a fall. Climbing speed can be increased at the price of increasing the risk. A fall is evenly distributed across the attempted climbing height.

One dimension is the time (in seconds), which it takes to achieve the wound level zero on the defender. The wound level is a separate dimension. You should use trajectories. Once a (rolled) progression has reached its goal, a new skill roll is necessary. It is therefore possible to play 10 second round-based combat.
The fractional parts for the higher values in the time dimension mean that multiple attacks “connect” at the same time. This is to avoid combat in split seconds.

Any effects from wounds or other external influences in combat are applied immediately to pending progressions, but the wound itself is modified by B/E/P of choice from the weapon and the appropriate armor. The offset is along the trajectory chosen. Note that the same is true for affects on the defender. If this implies an action to occur in the past, it is resolved immediately.
Use the same dimension as the Melee combat, but do not modify the time dimension below 5s. Reloading a crossbow takes 10s.
Wounds are treated as penalty to activity that involves the affected body part instead of damage to heal. Such wounds are reduced to zero, once the grapple is no longer maintained.
The time dimension is the time it takes to pick up a dropped item - this is a combat dimension.

Read Endurance as Healingrate for Fatigue, see Stamina. Remember that the fatigue accrued must be used as modifier for the next time interval. Standard healing rate is one point per minute. Also consider the increased fatigue rate for carrying heavy loads, see Strength.
The resolution is in mm/m or m/km. Typical modifications are made for contrast (positive), movement (positive), distraction (negative), on the border of the visual field (negative).
Fishing uses the Fast Yield dimension. The base yield is one manday of food. Abundance of fish gives a modifier between -20 and +20.
The ability to make and repair bows and arrows. Base yield is 1/4 bow or 3 arrows, which assumes tools and materials are available. Use the Slow Yield dimensions.

Fishing uses the Fast Yield dimension. The base yield is one manday of food. Different climate and terrain types may be specialties. Areas near civilization are likely to have a penalty of at least 10. Excellent conditions exist only in tropical rain-forests and special places like the Shava Forest with 10 bonus. Season is highly relevant. To seek specific plants, see Herblore. For hunting, see Tracking. Use the Fast Yield dimensions.
-20: Rural Silence
-10: Whisper
0: Low Speech
10: Normal Speech
20: Carts, Wagons, Combat
30: Smith, Stone Quarry, Skirmish
40: Thunder

Different regional/cultural types may be specialties. The skill uses the Recipe and Accuracy dimensions. One describes the achievements a character can actively reproduce/draw, the other the recognized achievements, if seen.

Different climate and terrain types may be specialties. The ability to find and identify individual types of plant. MLU is modified according to the plant’s rarity, seeking a plant in an inappropriate locale should also reduce ML. Use the Recipe, Accuracy and Fast Yield dimensions. The former dimension describes the recognized herbs, if seen. Trajectories are commonplace.

Initiative reflects battle experience, discipline, and morale. Initiative determines the speed in which characters can assess a stressful situation. Instead of rolling a general awareness roll, the characters take the time listed before they can act. An ambush and similar situations can give a bonus (for the ambushing party) as can the general awareness that combat is imminent. Sleeping and other unawareness situations may incur hefty penalties.

During the time a character is “frozen” this way, he is trying to understand the situation he is in and assesses the options he has. He is cautious during that time. General awareness issues such as during an ambush are not covered by Initiative.

Battle-hardened characters may come into the fractional range often. Optionally fractions can be used to determine who goes first. The GM determines, whether going first impedes the action of another already in the second that action culminates. This changes the drama of simultaneous activity, which may or may not be appropriate.

Jumping is tested when a character attempts to leap for height or distance. Results assume a running start; for standing jumps, halve heights and distances. Results below 0 turn into a Fall. For each 5 levels of dimension that are also accepted as fall, increase ML by 1 point.

This dimension can be exploited as knowledge and the knowledge about knowledge, i.e. how sure is the character that his reproduction of the knowledge is correct. Some example task difficulties follow.
0: Character barely knows the domain for such knowledge exists. With some luck, he can guess whether a general topic belongs to that domain or not.
10: The basic concepts are known, the more esoteric concepts have been heard of but cannot be applied.
20: Almost all concepts of the domain are known and can be applied with confidence. Only a few topics escape the grasp.
30: All of the domain is understood with ease. It is hard to find unknown territory, although it exists. Improvement of the art is possible.
40: Mastery of the subject matter as far as humanly possible. Genuine research or creation of new substance is possible.
A fatigue rate of 1 fatigue level per minute is multiplied be the result in the table. Mental Conflict is resolved similar to normal combat.

Humans can accelerate and decelerate as 3 m/s each second. Turning options are in parts of a full circle (centered around the direction of travel). E.g. at 3 m/s this means 60° off the direction of travel on either side per second. For the sake of playability variance in this should be suppressed, although a 20% spread (for a 10 level difference) with Agility modification could be appropriate.
Since steeds and (animal-powered) vehicles are important on Hârn, the table is extended beyond the human range. Humans max out at 9m/s at optimum.

A steed’s movement rate must be declared before starting to move. Effective movement is equal to its Move minus Steed Physical Penalty, then indexed in the Move table to find speed. Horses have four rates of speed: Walk/40, Trot/60, Canter/80, and Gallop/100. The number indicates the maximum speed that can be reached. All speeds are available at all riding skills, although commanding the horse to use it may prove a challenge. Horses/Steeds accelerate and decelerate at 6 m/s each second, but have the same turning options.

Rotation (also while standing) takes 1 second for 360 degree revolution (Acrobatic tricks apply) for bipeds, which is modified by physical penalty and rounded off. Horses take 1 second for 90 degrees, modified and rounded in the same way.

Use Physician skill to determine an improvement for the healing rate (see Stamina). Note that the presence of a physician improves the healing rate even further. The injury points are subtracted as penalty to determine the healing bonus.
This skill is not learned as usual but improved through righteous actions; it can decline just as fast through improper ones.
All Talents are treated as separate skills.

The Quality dimension can be used when a craftsman attempts to produce an item from raw materials. The result is an added to the base value to find the new value. An item with quality less than its base is usually broken. The results obtained do not necessarily reflect market value. Just because an item has +5 quality to its base does not mean anyone will pay the difference in pence. Some finished goods may involve several stages of enhancement. Uncut gems may be enhanced by cutting and then further enhanced by mounting in a gold-based necklace. Sometimes an item’s resistance to damage is more important than how beautiful it looks. Examples of this are weapon- and armour-crafting.
Quality is the net roll divided by 10. I.e. -5 through +4 results in 0, +5 through +14 results in 1, -15 through -6 results in -1, and do on.

For NPCs the associated table can be used to estimate the number of different recipes they know how to create. PCs should rather keep a book and start with what their master has given them. Self-made dabblers start with zero (0) and would need to do research. Recipes have a wide range of meaning, from classic cooking to tricks the character can teach to animals. It includes ritual or magic invocations.

Multiple orators may compete for the “airwaves” and hinder each other more than they realize. Therefore only two actors may combine their skills through 5-Addition if working in concert, thereafter it is only the maximum, if no competition takes place. If a competition takes place, the difficulty is a 5-Addition instead.

Healing time is given for one injury point. Subtract the number of injury points a wound has twice. Add a potential physician’s bonus once when determining the healing rate for the wound. An effective healing rate can be improved with a physician present. Note that a reduction in the effective wound points does not cause re-evaulation of the effective healing rate.

The listed weight (excluding your own body) can be lifted as maximum when you apply the dimension of the table below to Strength. For longer periods of lifting, apply the dimension to Endurance to get a maximum carry load (MCL). Fatigue rate is determined as the precentage of the real load carried divided by MCL multiplied by 10/minute.

Difficulty of swimming conditions is rated on the Beaufort scale. Test Swimming once for each continuous swim without rest. Any interruption requires a new roll. With a result below 0 the character starts to sink. Consider currents for speed determination. A swimmer accumulates one Fatigue Level for every minute of swimming at speed, but may rest by treading water. A resting swimmer rolls to see if they sink, but does not move (except with the current). Underwater Swimming is at half speed. When attempting to convey a conscious swimmer, apply a penalty of 5, for an unconscious person apply a penalty of 10.

If a character is in water deeper than their height, a Sink result implies the character goes down with the speed of the negative result. (I.e. -5 means going down at 0.5 m/s.) A reroll may be attempted every second, but fatigue applies immediately.
The distance thrown in meters is the n5 roll doubled. E.g. a character with MLU of 15 and a roll of +4 throws a suitable object for a distance of 38 meters.
Different climate types may be specialties. The ability to predict the weather. Characters with this skill may attempt to predict the weather any time. Also use the Accuracy dimension.
The Time dimension assumes a 12h workday, thus the apparent jump from 12h to 2 days.

At the beginning of each combat the players and GM should jointly decide which action options they want to allow and which will simply be abstracted by a set penalty/bonus by the GM. This can speed up combat tremendously. If tactical options outside of combat are affected by the decision, the GM should inform the players of that. For instance, if mounted combat is to tedious today, than the PCs might just as well dismount already to allow for smoother combat resolution. The main option Melee and Missile should never be removed.

In order to simulate larger combats with many participants, the usual 5-Addition can be used. It does not provide as many tactical options as individual combat does, but greatly reduces time spent. Both time and wound dimension should be scaled linearly with the number of particpipants. E.g. a wound of 5 after 30 seconds would scale to a total of 50 points after 5 minutes for 10 people or to 500 points after 50 minutes for 100 people. The points should be distributed in reasonable batches on the participants on each side, the smallest batch size being the wounds rolled. People can be hit multiple times, but points beyond 40 generally don’t make sense unless explosives, catapults, or similar are involved.

Fatigue gained by any conflict recovers at one Fatigue Level every minute. With dissolution, fatigue turns into injury. Note that spirits can take arbitrary injury before being destroyed and may heal forever. Only in rare cases (e.g. divine intervention) can spirits be destroyed.
Use the Move skill to determine speed. Subtract 2 from Missile ML for being mounted. To avoid lengthy calculations, subtract 50% of the attacker speed in m/s.

Because the potential exists to attack/influence entities that come within range, each character has an Engagement Zone of 1m plus weapon length radius about his center (that does not extend into blocked areas). The Engagement Zone of a conscious, prone character is only half that around his body. This means a standing character is often not engaged by an adjacent prone enemy, although the prone character may be engaged by the standing character. Similarly, two adjacent prone characters often do not engage each other. Unconscious characters have no Engagement Zones (not even the space their own body occupies) but may constitute obstacles. A character may be (melee) attacked upon entering an enemy’s Engagement Zone until he leaves that zone. This entering or leaving may be active or passive. It is possible to be engaged with an arbitrary number of enemies at a time. A character with a long reach weapon has an appropriately larger engagement zone and may therefore be eligible to attack before others. This may be of importance for mounted Charges into a row of Pikemen. Also note the restriction on using long weapons at short range. If combat extends into the third dimension, assume the volumetric “center” of a character to be a 1m vertical line centered on their true center (when upright). Horses have a two meter long horizontal line (when upright) centered on their true center. More bizarre creatures may have more bizarre engagement zones, even when not fighting in three dimensions.

Requiring a steed to halt may imply multiple attacks due to deceleration restrictions. Every engagement along the way may attack the steed/rider as usual. If the intent is to cause little damage, use the unintentional hit rules for melee (see below). Otherwise consider the group passed by to be the target and scale as per wild result in the missile attack section. Instead of the 60 degrees +/-2 distance, collect all in the path of 5 feet width. Any attacker plunging into defenders with an attack will decelerate at maximum rate, and that automatically determines the length of the path and the duration of the ride. At the riders discretion this can be broken down into separate attacks. A forced deceleration beyond what is normally allowed results in a fall impact for the rider and steed as from height equal to the forced decelaration minus the maximum allowed deceleration. E.g. 10 m/s end speed with a possible allowed decelaration of 3 m/s equals a fall from 7 m. Note that the fall impact also applies the targets fallen into. This is the charge bonus, where the deceleration is not deducted. For opportunistic melee attacks, this is also a direct penalty to the Dodge skill. A rider is not forced to halt his steed, but it usually requires a riding maneuver to not cause the steed to halt on its own, fire or similar incentives notwithstanding.

The push attempt must be in the direction the attacker is facing and the attacker must follow. The defender has a choice to evade into a semi-circle of up to 120 degrees, assuming no obstacles. Instead of Injury points, the number of meters pushed are used. The defender is forced to deduct the move from his action allowance, regardless of whether he resists or not. A resist deducts from the distance forced and can even be used as a counter-push. The pushed character may opt to fall prone instead at any time, for instance to avoid falling of a cliff. Any remaing distance is forfeit.
Rise: Use Acrobatics skill.
Grope: Use Dexterity skill.

The rider and horse may act in unison and add their combat skill per 5-Addition. Both accrue the same fatigue. Hitting the wrong target can happen in melee combat. Usually this is ignored, but if this ignorance is taken into account (out-world) when deciding on options, such accidents shall be played out. Anybody within the range of the weapon is subject to a skill roll with MLU 0. This can be added to the benefit of other attackers as per multiple attacks above or resolved individually with the goal of 0 damage.

For throwing arbitrary objects, use Throwing skill. Since missile attacks are resolved with individual shots, a missed attack is applied only if the intended attack had no impact. Count all potential targets completely in an arc of 30 degrees and +/-2 range levels of the intended target. Use 5-Addition of zeroes, but reduce by 5 for the missed, intended opponent. If a hit is scored on the much larger “super-target”, roll which individual target is hit by distributing evenly among all the unintended targets. When determining hit chances and damage apply the size modifier from the Size table below. At GM discretion, inanimate objects not participating in the skirmish may be counted as potential targets, particularly, if the actual targets are spread widely across the area. This increases can be used purposefully and can be quite devastating when firing at advancing troops. The Missile Attack table below reduces calculation for playability. Penetrating hits are ignored, i.e. no shots through multiple targets. The assumed skills rolls all use 0 damage and MLU of 0.

Use Unarmed Combat skill when no weapon is involved. The basic radius of the two characters engaged is 5-added. Multiple Grapples are allowed , but keep track of the grappled weapons of all opponents, they can no longer be used to full potential. Also observe any secondary considerations for odd Grapple attempts, e.g. grappling a horse’s hind leg.

For dodging, use Dodge skill. Dodge and Block/Parry are added through 5-Addition, if used together. Dodge/parry is mostly used at the same time an attack is contemplated by the defender himself. To ease calculation, only every defense beyond one attacker causes a -5 penalty in the next 10 seconds. E.g., the first attacker is defended at full MLU, the second at MLU-5 and the third is at MLU-10 and sone on. Note that that this is in addition to potential 5-addition of potential attackers’ MLU. If attackers coordinate in this manner, the defense MLU is not 5-added, but the penalty is averaged. Also note that Dodge is at -5 for high velocity missile attacks.
Steed Trample: Use steed ML (and penalties) only.
Remember the Reach of Long weapons. Usually Steed Stumble Roll, followed by an Unhorsing Roll is necessary to continue a Charge into polearms (assuming the Steed Command Check was successful).
div.h5: Esoteric Attack/Defense, Dropping Items, Ignore, Mount/Dismount, Mounted Move
div.p: No further out-world explanation is necessary. If useful, subactions here and elsewhere can be extracted that should become possible during a specific out-world handling of combat. Rewrite the rules here to accomodate this. The missing tactical option is compensated by an appropriate penalty/bonus if the action is still taken in-world.

The Attacker may declare one Main area as not being hit for a penalty of 1 to MLU. This choice can be taken multiple times, but the remaining Main locations must remain (bodily) connected. If all but one Main location has been eliminated, individual percentage points may be reduced for a Detail area. This penalty can again be taken multiple times but the remaining Detail hit locations must be (bodily) connected. The GM may restrict or penalize the choice of Aiming Zone if the attacker could only reach certain target zones with the declared attack weapon. A prone attacker would find it difficult to aim high on a standing opponent with a melee weapon. The Size table can be used, if the target is smaller than man-sized. This effect does not cummulate with aiming for parts of a target (the main part of this paragraph). There is no modification for man-sized creatures, unless the target offers a smaller effective target, but it may be combined with unintentional hitting (see above). A prone man, for example, presents a target about 2 feet tall, and a crouching man about 4 feet tall. Similar height adjustments may apply to other targets at GM discretion.
A character who is attacking (or being attacked by) a prone enemy increases Attack/Defense MLU with that character by 4.

A stop from a sprint/charge faster than the maximum natural deceleration rate may be necessary. (Running into a wall or head on into another opponent that doesn’t dodge.) In that case consider the distance that is not available to stopping as fall. Surface is considered at 30°. This damage is taken by the steed (or the runner). An appropriate strike location should be chosen. If the obstacle is reasonably capable of taking damage apply it there too. (If desired, use physics of an inelastic collision, i.e. when running into a wagon that starts to roll when run into. Damage always applies to both parties of a collision.) Also see Charge.

Subtract 1 for each significant impediment reaching into an engagement zone in the direction of the two enemies. For Multiple impediments only choose the greater intrusion. A blanket counts as significant, as does a wooden beam. A feather bush does not.

Any new wound of at least 1 point to arms results in a Fumble chance. Use accumulated damage to that extremity and fatigue as difficulty for a Dexterity skill roll against 0. Failure results in dropping anything held on that arm. If something is held in both hands, 5-add the difficulties and the two Dexterity EMLUs.

Any new wound of at least 1 point to legs results in a stumble chance. Use accumulated damage to that extremity and fatigue as difficulty for an Agility skill roll against 0. Failure results in dropping prone. Each additional leg after the first can be 5-added.

Any new wound of at least 1 point results in a Shock chance. Use accumulated injury and fatigue as difficulty for a Stamina skill roll against 0. Failure results in unconsciousness for a time indiciated in the Shock table. Unconscious people cannot eat and drink. Someone in Shock for more than 10 days will likely never wake up again.
Instead of (autonomous) Healing, Repair must be applied externally. Use the appropriate Craft skill instead of Physician.

Weapon and Armor make a Shock roll for the damage that they absorb, respectively deal. Weapon Quality (WQ) is used instead of Stamina skill and damage is not accumulated. Armor works the same way, but the instead if Stamina, sum up BEPF. Failure means a weapon or armor breaks, which may potentially be repaired as above. Any ML additions that are multiples of 10 need to be downgraded to 40% as MLU modifier and multiples of 5 are downgraded to 60%. Otherwise the combat charts are used as written.

Strike location is important for two main reasons. First, only the armour worn at the location struck is relevant. Second, injury effects vary by location; a blow to the skull is more serious than a blow to the foot. The percentages allocated to body parts do not reflect the relative size of that part, since the head, arms, or groin are favored targets. Combatants can influence Strike Location by targeting their aim. Although combatants instinctively turn to face the most imminent threat, some armour only covers part of a strike location - a breastplate, for example, only covers the front of the thorax and abdomen. In random situation, where it is hard to determine whether the front or back of a strike location is struck, experience shows there is a 75% chance of being struck on the front side. An asterisk (*) indicates that Stumble or Fumbles may apply.

Combatants who sustain Serious or Grievous wounds may die during the healing routine. On the other hand, various types of magic, miracles, Psionics, and potions can improve healing. The following wound types exist and individual wounds are tracked with their location. Effects on the use of the corresponding part are described below.

When the following text says, adjacent body parts are affected, effects include penalties (which are not cumulative but take the maximum) infection chance and bloodloss (also not cumulative but take the maximum). They are not recursive, i.e. do not imply secondary effects. To determine which penalty applies to which activity use common sense and GM discretion.
1-5: Minor. Wounds only have wound penalty.

5-10: Serious. Wounds of this type also have minor effects on neighbouring detailed body parts at 5 points less. Any activity involving these body parts are at the appropriate penalty. These effect wounds do not heal separately.

11-15: Grievous. The detailed body part cannot be used, serious use effects on neighbouring detailed body parts, and minor on neighboring main parts. (This might only be the including main part.) These effect wounds do not heal separately. Minor effects are at 10 less than the Grievous, while serious are 5 less.

16-20: Incapacitating, the main body part cannot be used, serious use effects on neighbouring main body parts. (For head this means unconsciousness and for thorax imminent death.) Serious effects are at 10 less than the incapacitating wound itself.

21+: Destroyed, the main body part lost its integrity, Grievous use effects on neighbouring main body parts. (For limbs this means at least severed. Thorax is split open or spinal cord severed. For all but the extremities this means instant death. For all other body parts, death is probably imminent due to the side effects.) Grievous use effects are at 10 less than the Destroyed wound itself.

Any wound needs to heal its injury points. This depends on Stamina; medicine may improve the healing rate. A physician may attempt to find or create the correct medicine. See the appropriate sections.

An untreated wound is considered as being treated by a Physician with the negative wound-level. E.g. a wound with 6 injury points is treated as if diagnosed by Physician with MLU -6. The standard treatments mostly known by all still need to be applied and detailed, so a physician’s diagnosis is always necessary. “Destroyed” wounds may be treated as incapacitating, with a Bonus on Diagnosis of 5. Note that the usage effects on bordering regions needs to be treated as well. Overtreatment is possible but has no specific negative impact.

A serious or worse wound may become infected until it turns into a minor wound. An infection is a daily attack on the wounded area with a level of the (remaining) injury points, defended against with Stamina.

Bloodloss is treated as a separate injury. Note that the circulatory system is incapacitated with points in excess of 15 points as other body parts are. The circulatory system itself will not turn infectious. Treatment by physicians depend on the location. Some locations are incurable by Hârnic physicians. For multiple bleeders only take the maximum in the same extremity, but add those for different extremities. Incapacitating and destroying wounds have no additional effects over the bleeder and infection dangers.
Infections, diseases, toxins, and other come in various forms. Bloodloss is already explained elsewhere, but repeated here for reference.

Bloodloss Once a wound in excess of 10 points is received, bloodloss is calculated. (Some form of damage do not create bloodloss, e.g. diseases.) This number is lost every 10 seconds until the treatment Compress is applied. Thereafter these points heal at 1 per day.

Infection An open wound with more than 5 injury points is attacked daily with MLU 0 until it has less than 5 points or is otherwise closed. The injury points start with 1 and are received 1 per watch until the infection has run its course. The healing rate is modified by all running infections’ points and the injury points of the wound in question.

Sleep deprivation Every watch after a Stamina roll against -20 in hours, with a penalty of 1 per hour of not having slept. For playability start rolling after 24h and the injury points are always 5. The points are regained at the rate of 1 per hour of sleep.

Thirst Every watch after a Stamina roll against -20, with a penalty of 1 for each liter of water that has not been drunk per day on average. For playability start rolling after 3 days without water have passed. Points are regained at the rate of 1 per hour.

Hunger Every day after a Stamina roll against -20, with a penalty of 1 for each two pounds of food that have not been eaten per day on average. For playability start rolling after 10 days without food have passed. Points are regained at the rate of 1 per hour.

Suffocation Every minute without air a Stamina roll against 0 is required, with a penalty of 5 for each consecutive minute without air. Points are regained at the rate of 1 per second once air is available again..

The talent has three dimensions: Range, Duration, and Language. The range is determined to reach the target and the other dimensions (trajectory) may be chosen by the user. The range is MLU in kilometers, and the duration is 30 seconds, halved or doubled for every 20 levels difference. Language is the effectiveness a concept can be shared. It is capped by a combined skill roll in a common language, if the recipient is willing. Otherwise it is capped by individual skill rolls.
